flashcards.back: Singhbhum & Ranchi, Chotanagpur. Leader: Raja of Parahat (Ho), Birsa Munda. Context: 1765 Chotanagpur came under British control as part of Bengal, Bihar, Orissa. Raja of Singhbhum initially sought protection from British in 1767 but acknowledged British feudal control in 1820. The Hos initially allied with British, eventually broke alliance and united with Mundas, leading to Kol Uprising (1831-33). Rebellion targeted dikkus (non-Adivasi landowners) through violence, including burning of houses and significant casualties. British land policies undermined traditional system, such as Khuntkatti system (joint tenures), and missionary activities undermined their traditional culture. Exploitation of land by moneylenders intensified suffering. Birsa Munda (1890s) became prominent leader, promoting social reforms like abstinence from alcohol and witchcraft, cleanliness, social reforms. Led armed rebellion against British authorities with goal to liberate tribal communities from British oppression and exploitation. Impact: The Ulgulan movement severely shook British rule in region. Chotanagpur Tenancy Act (1908) enacted to protect tribal rights. Legacy: Birsa Munda revered as tribal hero and symbol of resistance against colonial oppression

Madhya Pradesh & Gujarat. Leader: Unspecified. Revolt against British authority and upper-caste Hindus. Tribal areas resisted increasing dominance of British and upper-caste interests. Focused on challenging colonial and caste oppression in these regions
Bihar. Leader: Unspecified. Kharwar tribes revolted to assert traditional rights and resist British revenue policies. Focused on opposition to British revenue settlement activities

flashcards.front: Bhuyan and Juang Rebellions (Late 19th to early 20th century)?
flashcards.back: Odisha. Leader: Ratna Nayak, Dharma Dhar Nayak. Resistance against British-imposed forest policies. Bhuyan and Juang tribes resisted British encroachment and restrictive policies on tribal forests
Chotanagpur. Leader: Unspecified. Extended period of revolts by Bokta community against British policies and land exploitation. Community fought for land rights and against colonial policies

Eastern Godavari tract of Andhra Pradesh and Malkangiri region in Odisha. Leader: Tomma Dora. Erosion of customary rights over forests, heavy taxes on timber and grazing, police exactions, exploitations by moneylenders, along with new excise regulations on toddy production. Tomma Dora led major revolt in 1880, seizing a police station, defeating British contingent, gaining title 'King' of Malkangiri. Following Tomma Dora's demise, Raja Anantayyar organised another revolt in 1886

Dabur Region, Visakhapatnam. Leader: Korra Mallaya. Korra Mallaya organised Khonda Doras to oppose British incursions in region. Led mobilisation efforts to protect local resources, autonomy, and resist British exploitation

Jagdalpur. Leader: Unspecified. Significant tribal uprising against feudal exploitation and forest levies. Tribes protested colonial exploitation and feudal structures that infringed on tribal land rights

Oraon tribes, Chotanagpur, Jharkhand. Leaders: Jatra Bhagat/Balram bhagat. Economic exploitation by landlords, moneylenders, and British. Swaraj (freedom) signified liberation from British oppression and local exploitation. Focused on eradicating social practices like worship of ghosts, spirits, exorcism. Influenced by Mahatma Gandhi's non-violence and satyagraha philosophy. Jatra Bhagat, claiming divine ordination, led movement which started in 1914. Used non-violent methods such as satyagraha, influencing resistance before Gandhi's Non-Cooperation Movement. Movement became significant part of tribal resistance. In 1921, Tana Bhagats allied with Congress, strengthening wider independence struggle
